39434421.review:
Ara Fell is simply delightful. There is a healthy balance between fun and an unfolding, intriguing story. The pixel art is beautiful. The characters have personality. The intrigue is such that I just wanted to skip work so I could keep playing this game! I enjoyed exploring as much of the world as I could without having to stick to the main quest and finding treasures.

The only downside is the lack of variance in characters' attack and skill effectiveness as you add points to attributes on level up. Also, the experience points you recieve later on from tougher enemies is not much more than that of the common weaker enemies. That may be a result of creating a freely explorable, open world but it was odd to me but not enough to detract from my overall experience.

If Secret of Mana and Chrono Trigger are your type of game, I would highly recommend Ara Fell. I do hope that the creators of this game make a sequel. I loved it!

38238155.review:
Nachdem ich Ara Fell nun durch habe, hier ein kurzes Review:

Für relativ wenig Münzgeld bietet Ara Fell gute 15-20 Stunden Spielzeit in einer atmosphärischen fantasy Welt 
mit Elfen, Menschen und Vampiren. 

Das Spiel selbst wurde mit dem RPG-Maker 2003 gemacht und ist damit zwar 
grafisch nicht so "aufwendig" wie von den moderneren RPG-Makern gewohnt, jedoch hat es seinen eigenen Charm. 
Ich persönlich bevorzuge die größeren Charactermodelle.
Weiterhin werden viele Spielmechaniken verwendet, die nicht standartmäßig beim RPG-Maker 2003 dabei waren. 
So kann man mit Shift krabbeln, um in Spalten und kleine Höhlen hineinzuklettern, schwimmen, an Kanten springen und man kann seine Helden nach einem Level-Up Skillpunkte zuweisen. Besondere Erwähnung soll hier das Crafting-System finden, dass ruhig etwas umfangreicher hätte sein können. Auch das Kampfsystem ist nicht standartmäßig und läuft teilweise in Echtzeit ab. Ebenso vorhanden ist eine Karte mit Questmarkern und Fog of War, ein Teleportsystem mit freischaltbaren Wegpunkten und ein Händler bei dem man, zugegeben wenige, neue Fähigkeiten erkaufen kann.

Von der Schwierigkeit  her sind die anfänglichen  Kämpfe etwas mühseelig, da man kaum Erfahrung oder Geld erwirtschaftet. Je länger man spielt, desto einfacher wird es allerdings. Fans des Grindings sollten wissen, dass man 
in diesem Spiel lieber auf die EP achten sollte als auf Geld, da dies wirklich knapp ist. Ein Level-Up bringt effektiv, zumindest meiner Ansicht nach, mehr als ein neues Rüstungsteil, da man eigentlich genügend davon durch Crafting und Truhen erhält. 

Die Geschichte, die das Spiel erzählt, ist nicht übermäßig spannend, hat aber seine Höhen. Es handelt sich um das gute alte Helden-Retten-Die-Welt Szenario. Ohne großartig etwas Spoilern zu wollen, kann man sagen, dass das Ende abschließend ist, dennoch trotzdem Platz für einen Nachfolger bietet. Dabei werden die meisten Fragen geklärt, die einem im Spiel einfallen. Zu der Hauptquest gibt es noch einpaar Nebenquests, die allerdings alle relativ kurz und unbedeutend sind. Mehr wäre auf alle Fälle schön gewesen, es hat aber definitiv gereicht um zu Leveln und extra Loot abzustauben. 

Alles in allem war das geld gut investiert und ich hatte viel Spaß daran dieses RPG-Maker spiel zu beenden. Daumen Hoch und weiter so! Weiter unten gibt es noch einpaar Tips, die ich so Spoilerfrei wie möglich halten werde.




TIPS: 
Nachdem der Hauptheld seinen AOE-Magieangriff lernt, kann man ruhig auf Intelligenz und Mana umskillen. Der reine DMG durch ATK ist niedriger als auf einer INT-Skillung und die Gegner sind größtenteils schwach gegen den AOE-Magieangriff.

Reflektieren des Tanks sollte so schnell wie möglich erlernt und beinahe bei sämtlichen Kämpfen als Eröffnungszug eingesetzt werden, da es so ziemlich alle AOE-Angriffe von Gegnern annuliert.

Spart es euch auch nur einen Punkt in ATK bei eurem Unterstützer zu verwenden, steckt 6 Punkte in DEF, 2-5 in AGI und den Rest in Mana und INT. Es gibt ein Item mit dem man mehr Mana regeneriert, dieses hilft Wunder.

Euer Magier sollte so schnell wie möglich 5-8 Punkte in DEF haben, danach alles in INT bis der Neutrale-AOE-Zauber freigekauft wurde. Hier besonders Interessant: Man kann eine Rüstung ohne Extrastats craften, die den Mana-Verbrauch halbiert. Diese erläubt es euch den Neutralen-Single-Target-Zauber mehrmals hintereinander zu casten und keine Manaprobleme zu bekommen. Mit 2 Punkten in MANA kann mann auch den AOE 2 mal hintereinander casten, was eigentlich für sämtliche Trashgruppen locker reicht.

37620908.review:
Lembro de quando conheci a primeira versão, incompleta, desse jogo, Ara Fell: The Legend of Dirisetsu Hollow, há uns 10 anos! Uma década depois, eu tive a improvável oportunidade de rever Ara Fell, novinho em folha, quase inteiramente refeito, na loja da Steam! Qual não foi minha surpresa!
Jogar de novo essa beleza foi nostálgico, mas também foi novo. E aqui começa a minha análise de fato, preciso ativar o modo Seri Kesu pra deixar de lado esse sentimentalismo :')

GRÁFICOS
O visual do jogo é belíssimo. Não me refiro aqui, logicamente, aos meros tiles de RPG Maker que muita gente já conhece muito bem. É mais do que isso. É o brilhantismo na utilização de elementos básicos, de forma a tornar os mapas cheios de vida. Animais saltam nos bosques, cristais brilham nas cavernas escuras. O jogo promete um mundo bonito e rico em exploração e é exatamente isso que ele entrega, sem, contudo, apelar para mapas intermináveis (se bem que o sistema de teletransporte ajudou nisso). Algo que ficou faltando, a meu ver, foi uma maior "diversidade urbana", por assim dizer. [spoiler]As cidades, com exceção de Orlian, são muito parecidas[/spoiler].

TRILHA SONORA
O jogo tem algumas músicas bem chiclete que vão dar o clima perfeito, e outras músicas que, apesar de menos expressivas, não destoam da atmosfera do jogo. Alguns efeitos sonoros e músicas realmente foram tão bem com as cenas, que me surpreenderam.

JOGABILIDADE
Jogar Ara Fell é tão simples quanto jogar os RPGs clássicos nos quais o jogo se inspira. Não há muito mistério, é praticamente só memorizar os comandos mais básicos e seguir com eles até o final do jogo. O sistema de batalhas por turnos com modo automático e o modo de história pode ajudar quem tem preguiça de lutar. E a customização dos personagens deu um quê a mais pra quem gosta de apelar com stats altíssimos (cof, cof, nunca fiz isso). O sistema de quests é simples e charmoso, me diverti bastante atendendo a tasks bem aleatórias. Dentro das dungeons, há puzzles legais de se fazer, mas acredito que muitos acharão bem fáceis. Nada tão desafiador.

HISTÓRIA
Deixei o melhor pro final, porque sinceramente... what in the Abyss was that?
O clima desse jogo é ao mesmo tempo leve e estranhamente pesado. A beleza da neve fina que cai do céu o tempo todo em Aloria não denuncia as guinadas sombrias que Ara Fell dá em alguns momentos. O jogo consegue soltar diversos mistérios no ar e resolver satisfatoriamente boa parte deles, enquanto desenvolve bem os personagens. Lita LeCotta, por exemplo, é uma das protagonistas femininas mais interessantes que já vi. Detalhes pequenos, às vezes negligenciados pelo jogador, podem revelar mais sobre alguém no jogo. Esteja no clima pra bons diálogos com mocinhos e vilões, porque vão rolar. Esteja no clima também pra um grupo de personagens principais com motivações sólidas pra se juntar a Lita na sua jornada, e pra um romance aqui e acolá, que ninguém é de ferro...

Em resumo, maravilhoso. Ara Fell é meu 10/10 dos jogos de RPG Maker <3

SPOILERZÃO DO FINAL POR SUA CONTA E RISCO:
[spoiler]Gente. Ara... fell? SERIOUSLY??! XD [/spoiler]

37536819.review:
This is a great RPGMaker game with beautiful pixel graphic, and a huge map many hidden areas to explore. I took my time with the game to explore every nook and cranny, so it took me around 20 hours to complete the game (do all side quests, check all the hidden areas)

Some highlight of my experience:
[list]
[*] You can choose between real time combat, where you need to make decision to attack as soon as you can move, or tinker with option to pause the clock when it's your turn. I changed to pause the clock, since I'm too slowpoke for real time.
[*] At one point in the storyline, [spoiler]when everyone is turned into stone[/spoiler], the game essentially gives you the freedom to access the places that you are not supposed to enter until later in the game, and I really love this open-world like nature of the game.
[*] The side quests in the game ranges from mundane fetch/delivery quest, or bounty quest (where you need to explore the map to find the target), to interesting ones where [spoiler]the item you find in the quest is better than the reward you get[/spoiler]
[*] There are many hidden areas to explore with loots to boost your power. Though there is a marked reduction of those later in the game.
[*] Point-based stats. You can freely choose how to distribute the stats for your character, instead of fixed increment amount for all stats when level up.
[*] Crafting system in this game is rather limited. From my experience, only a few (level 4 items) are worth crafting
[/list]

While there are rough edges here and there (especially as you progress in the game), this is a game worth playing if you like RPG games.

37413305.review: Nice story, decent ending, and overall a fun game to play.  It is certainly worth your time.

37124876.review:
Rich world-building environment with emotional characters, and interesting NPCs; harkening back to the depth of feel of older classics like Final Fantasy 6. They even patched in an epilogue to offer a glimpse into the future of the characters' lives after the events of the story, which does a good job in finalizing the chapter of Ara Fell.

Pros:
- Rich Story
- Character development
- Ability to control stat level-ups is cool
- Controls
- The soundtrack is amazing!

Cons:
- Very easy, with no hard mode option (more below)
- Character development (yes, both pro and con)
- Replayability is non-existent. One and done, no reason to revisit.


--Character development
On one hand, the characters have great detail and a clearly developed personality. This is wonderful and helps to engage in the story, because the characters actually care about the world and its inhabitants. Some even have growth as they endure the story's hardships/uptimes, and character arcs that unfold as the story progresses.

On the other hand, some characters seem devoid of character growth [spoiler] Seri Kesu ... she was so amazing, but grew/revealed so little [/spoiler] or end with a real left-field head scratcher [spoiler] Looking at you, Talani and Doren. Granted, I burst out laughing at the bluntness of it. [/spoiler] - which is sad because they are so cool and they deserve more growth/reasoning.

-- About it being easy
I found the game super easy, to the point I nearly felt it impossible to lose a battle. Granted; I'm good at these types of games. Just to try to keep the battles somewhat entertaining, I purposefully NEVER equipped top-tier equipment on my characters and left old armor on them instead of upgrading -- or used the armor that provided No Stats (but half MP bonus is crazy). For that purpose; you can mitigate this issue by NOT equipping strong gear(which you can acquire very fast), then the battles can be somewhat more entertaining.

I wouldn't have said anything about this if there were a "Hard mode" option available for us veterans/fans. It would offer a form of replayability.


Overall? I would say this game is worth a play, even at the full $10. I have heard the author is working on a sequel, and do intend on purchasing it when it is released.

36670731.review:
A beautiful little gem of an RPG that brought me right back to the older Final Fantasy titles and time spent with lots of turn-based RPGs on my GameBoy Advance. I didn't know what to expect at all when I bought Ara Fell; I noticed that someone on my friend list had it and the premise seemed interesting enough and the art, like I mentioned above, made me super nostalgic. I figured there would be no harm in trying it out! 

But wow. After completing Chapter 1 of the game my feelings went from vaguely interested to actually invested. And it is so rare for me to get so emotionally invested in a game's story and characters so quickly, but Ara Fell did it. What I thought would have been a cliché story actually ended up surprising and shocking me on many occasions. (I also may or may not have teared up once or twice.) 

This game shines in its ability to do so much with dialogue and pacing (Lita can be downright hilarious), in the way it is grounded in its lore and world-building (without spoiling, the plot reveals, revelations, and raising of the stakes were all really well done), while not falling* too heavily on combat or exposition, and in creating memorable characters that I ended up truly caring for and looked forward to seeing again (Seri Kesu may just be one of my favorite video game characters of all time). 

All of these elements, combined with a touching, engaging soundtrack and surprisingly powerful atmosphere, make Ara Fell one of the best RPGs I've played this year. So happy that I didn't let this game pass me by. Also, as I saw that the epilogue was added on a bit after the game's initial release - I have to say that for me, personally, it was greatly appreciated. It gave me a much-needed sense of closure after completing the main story of Ara Fell that I would have been otherwise searching for had I been left with the pre-epilogue ending. 

*Can I get a +1 for my first time ever using a pun in a review?

Thank you so, so much for sharing a bit of one of your worlds with us, Stegosoft Games! I'm already looking forward to whatever journey you'd like to take us on next!

Just finished playing Ara Fell.  I recommend it heartily to anyone who enjoyed Final Fantasy 6 (or III as it will always be to those of us old guys who played it on the SNES).  Though Ara Fell is nowhere near as long (or as complicated, battle-system wise) as that game, so don't go into it expecting a 60-hour playthrough.

36584606.review:
Ara Fell has a classic feel, charming spritework, little environmental touches to help with verisimilitude, and characters to care about. While I had some issues with the game, ultimately I found it to have a lot of heart. It won me over, and I can't wait to see the next title from these developers.

Most of the game's emotional moments felt impactful. The way the game presented the characters and their plight was effective. Sparing use of blood and death heightened the stakes.

The battle systems and stat progression could have done with some rebalancing. The plethora of gear and stat combinations you can come up with seems to invite experimentation, but all the skills/spells scale heavily on Intelligence - even the physical attack skills. Around the midpoint, this leads to a dominant strategy of giving all of your party members high Intelligence, and using multitarget attacks to win. Once the sorceress character is available, the game seems to encourage doubling down on this tactic. I liked the idea of the freeform level up system, but in practice it didn't quite work out. That said, I still loved seeing my characters level up and giving them more stat points. Certain rewards seem to never get old.

Some of the music could have used a few more compositional ideas, but I enjoyed the texture and contemplative feel of the soundtrack. For example, the music during the prologue adventure had an attractive air of mystery, and it made me want to learn more about the story and game world.

For the next title from Stegosoft Games, I feel that a more flexible game engine would suit them better than RPG Maker and its limitations. I suspect not being able to move the menu cursor during a battle animation was one such limitation. I would love to see a choice of engine that allows their vision to flourish, as I so enjoyed their storytelling and characters. The RPG Maker stock sound effects are serviceable, but I hope to hear assets of a bit higher quality in their next title.

Despite my complaints, I think this game will stick with me. I am glad I played it.

36502247.review:
4/10
Sou capaz de ver semelhança entre as razões que as pessoas aplaudem Skyrim com as que gostam de Ara Fell, parece-me que o fascínio por um jogo que amplifique seu conteúdo via interações e valor explorativo seja incalculável. Tudo bem que as coisas destinaram-se viver desse modo, porém, esses tais méritos não foram eficazes para convencer-me de que este jogo é bom, e vou explicar-te o motivo.

O sistema de combate detém os componentes primordiais dos modelos de luta dos JRPGs. Seu tempo é fragmentado em passagens (turnos), durante os quais as unidades terão a capacidade de atuar em ordem mais ou menos fixa (postarei as opções de jogadas nos comentários). Há uma barra de potência que tua equipe e os adversários retêm que recarrega-se em todo instante que não estiver cheia, e quando estiver, terás a oportunidade de efetuar teu seguinte ataque. Dentro do contexto de nossos inimigos entretanto, são qualificados para atacar-te na hora em que não tiveres o personagem anteposto para fazer a próxima ação, que é uma ocasião sempre decorrente quando sua esquadra finaliza algum turno. A primeira agressão é sem falta cometida por ti, portanto não necessitas preocupar-te com isto - se bem que, não digo concedendo-me a favor da ideia de que haverá momentos em que o tormento se formará, pois o jogo inteiro é acessível para quaisquer tipos de dedicação exposta para prosseguir na narrativa. Há ausência de profundura e essa ausência que digo-te, espanca-te sem demora já no rudimento. Essa falta de minúcias para perturbar-se nas táticas abertas para optar ao combater os inimigos traz dilatadas saudades, pois as possibilidades que existem são fáceis de distinguir suas virtudes levando nós todos a conceber um método mental para separa-las e concluir quais são as mais adequadas para se usar, e quando seu superior valor é comprovado, a heterogeneidade dos ataques inimigos e tão minima que não fará com que esses rendimentos não sejam re-utilizados junto a outros que se encaixam em determinadas ocorrências, ou seja, a não ser que você esteja jogando feito pândego, não há como perder. Sem falar que, ninguém é obrigado a optar por novas ideias e arriscar obter sérias consequências, porque não há sérias consequências! A diferença de dificuldade entre um duelo e o outro é só apoiado pela duração. Alguns inimigos farão com que você aproveite alguns turnos para conservar sua equipe, e já que não estarás levando o inimigo até a morte nesses minutos, isso criará uma extensão obrigatória na durabilidade do duelo. Resumindo, se você fez merda então a partida só irá durar mais, que não é risco algum! Porque só pode um bobo perder poderio máximo a respeito da conjuntura! Essa facilidade desenvolve um uso repetível das mesmas paternas possíveis durante o jogo inteiro, tornando o grind um ensejo menos proficiente uma vez que ele seja mais tedioso do que como normalmente seria em demais jogos. Esses problemas poderiam ser anulados se houvessem alguma elegância estética nesse fronteira da jogabilidade, mas, com infelicidade, afirmo que pouco há. Para quem está pouco se lixando, existe um item que você pode optar por ter em seu inventário que faz com que você pule qualquer luta que bem preferir, e no processo, ganharás os utensílios e xp que ela daria-te.

O mundo exibe na primeira vista bastante conteúdo exploratório, é espiritoso caçar por baús, deparar em ruínas, exterminar chefões raros e assim por diante, mas, este conteúdo vai limitando-se pós um terço da história, verás que a paisagem com neve por exemplo, quase não dura em quesitos de vastidão de espaço. Além disso, averiguar não está rico em graça quando tu percebe que é impossível se juntar a ladra com fantasia de coelho. Sério, os exemplares que dei acima na cruel realidade abreviam bem toda experiência que é buscar por segredos. Não há aparência única ao plano material em arquétipos de regiões escondidas, só são cavernas como todas as outras, ora! Além do mais que não é inescusável os utensílios dados nos baús posto que atropelar todos os desafios de Ara usando outros procedimentos é tranquilo. Nenhum item inclusive, tem algo para usufruir esteticamente, só são meios de fortalecer as estatísticas dos personagens.

Eu aprecio muito os visuais, a variedade de cenários aguardando o jogador familiarizar-se é o regular para uma narrativa com longevidade de 15 horas, há ruínas, cavernas, florestas, vilarejos e fortalezas, todas estas, prósperas de detalhes que pode-se afirmar o seu bem proveito, pois, senhoreiam a alternância de sprites despejados ao espaço, que combinam com o clima reproduzido. O mundo físico que o lugar toma conta é bem agradável e leve, com uma colorização um tanto que aproveitada sem uso de técnicas que tornariam-a caliginosa, digo na fé aos que prezam ilhas flutuantes no céu que, esse jogo conquistaria-os nos aspectos visuais. Evidentemente é observável o belo esforço para adicionar detalhes que dão vida ao entorno, presumo que o desenvolvedor tenha uma fixação com a natureza, pois é aqui que encontra-se o foco principal das características que tornam o mundo vivo e ativo, os ecossistemas e os fenômenos da natureza vinculados a presença de personagens humanos e suas criações. Cada persona, com sua própria individualidade e indenidade. Seus retratos nas caixas de texto vareiam de acordo com a expressão que o autor quis refletir neles, dão uma formosa concepção de como eles estão pensando caso o próprio texto em si não faça-se o papel de obvio. [As expressões melancólicas entretanto, são bobas :compa:]

A escrita similarmente ao enredo, é simples. Enquanto o diálogo procura acrescentar mais conteúdo histórico em sua erudição, outrossim tem a fixação em conteúdo conotativo, esse elemento é a fonte principal do enriquecimento das personalidades, pois, é aqui que é demonstrado sua fortuna via humor, expressões, estado de espírito e exteriorização de seus pensamentos. Vendo pelo lado negativo, a parte conotativa dos diálogos não tem sua inomogeneidade tão notória, ou seja, a personalidade de um objeto que possuí recepção via texto seguirá uma natureza constante, sem nenhum desenvolvimento ou adições de peculiaridades percebíveis, a não ser nas ocorrências em que a narrativa precisar de uma pequena mudança no caráter para conseguir fluir em suas ambições. Resumindo, a protagonista continuará ceticista, vulnerável e um tanto que grossa até o final do jogo, um dos vilões, continuará pretensioso, sereno e um baita de um filho da puta durante esta mesma duração, pô! Na hora em que juntamos esses aspectos para julgar a apresentação em seu todo, percebemos que tudo é expressado de modo explícito, sem que vós tenha quaisquer dificuldades em entender a historia usando só a impressão, faltam também elementos que façam com que você deva refletir para cargar certeza com as conclusões que chegastes com o acumulo de recipientes da narrativa, este, estraga bastante o espírito de nossa curiosidade. Expõem tanto das mensagens que querem transmitir que faz com que limite nossas expectativas e imaginação, nossas hipóteses sobre o que vai acontecer por próximo se tornam quase retóricas e as surpresas encontrarão-se menos excitantes do que poderiam ser se estivéssemos na ausência deste estilo. Logo no começo por exemplo, você sabe distinguir os antagonistas e que eles verdadeiramente carregam males com justificativas que não são-te o suficiente para tolera-los, ou os inúmeros personagens lembrando-te na sua face da possibilidade de houver um romance entre a protagonista e seu amigo. Não precisa estar claro no texto mas na função da linguagem poética. A historia corre um percurso genérico, várias cenas recicladas e uma criação de novos problemas só para dar-te mais chefões com quem lidar, não sei aonde o diretor leu que torção no enredo significa "traição" e que deva existir inúmeras durante a historia para torna-la um valimento considerável para a conclusão de todos que fecharam o jogo pós termino.

36318055.review:
[b]A cast of relatable characters and a world you'll want to get to know are highlights in this ode to 16-bit RPGs.[/b]

[i][u]Summary:[/u][/i]
It's surprising that some oversized pixels, a bit of text and a simple emotive melody can evoke such shivers across your skin or lumps in your throat.  But they can, and this game does. This is a game for those of us who love the story-centric RPGs of old (Final Fantasy 4 & 6, Chrono Trigger). However, it may disappoint those in it for the tactical combat (Final Fantasy 5 & Tactics).

While Ara Fell doesn't nail every aspect, none of its flaws are enough to hamstring an otherwise great game. A few examples include combat that is rewarding for a while but some oversimplification of mechanics leads to many fights playing out the same way. The story and level design leading up to the end feel a little rushed. Puzzles are another weak point.

But you won't care because you'll want to see how these characters will grow and reveal more of themselves to you over time. You'll wonder what's beyond this bridge choked with fearsome trolls. You'll thirst for that next big equipment upgrade and a challenging boss to use it against.

I should note that this is a shorter game than those that inspired it. It took me 18.8 hours to fully explore, do side quests and complete the game. In that time it tells a complete and satisfying story. It may be on a smaller scale, but it feels a little bit more intimate.

[u][i]Full review:[/i][/u]
I really enjoyed the writing in Ara Fell. There is no voice acting but each character still has a distinct voice because of the way they are written. They all have their own flaws, quirks, mysteries and struggles. Character portraits depicting different emotions fill in nicely for voice tone and body language. Frequent light hearted moments and a few running gags keep the mood light. I did notice a few typos and spot genre tropes at times, but nothing near enough to ruin the experience.

It's not just the heroes that are well written but the villains as well. Not all of them are as fleshed out as I would have liked, but those that are display motivations deeper than the raw evil you often see. While their actions are still wrong, they do become more understandable once you've seen their perspective. Their past is integral to the lore of this magical land in the sky. I like how distant history is poorly kept in Ara Fell because it forces you to constantly question whether the information you come across is myth or reality.

Non-story related NPC dialogue is competent but could have used more depth and variety to truly shine. It is better earlier on in the game but thins out later on. There is enough change in what they have to say after major events in the story to make this world seem reasonably alive.

The recently added epilogue is a very welcome addition. I can see how the original ending was too abrupt right after the climax. Now we get closure while still leaving the door open to a sequel.

Battles follow a familiar turn based system where each party member has their own specialization. It's main unique feature is that MP pools are small but quickly recharge, allowing you to make liberal use of special skills. There is an unfortunate lack of variety and progression in skills though. Once you gain access to a character they'll either already have all their skills or will quickly learn the rest of them.  Having a single, full party buff spell on the healer means you'll start every boss battle by using that spell, without question. Seemingly in an attempt to streamline, the developers forgot that having options is more fun. Thankfully, frequent bosses do a decent job of shaking things up with their own gimmicks.

If there is a sequel I hope to see puzzles removed or vastly improved. I'd say that this is Ara Fell's weakest feature. Some are so simple as to be merely busy work. Dragging a brazier onto a glowing spot of the floor presents zero challenge when you can both push and pull. It's impossible to get stuck yet they have a floating orb nearby that allows you to reset the puzzle. There was really only one puzzle that I thought was good and it was a central element to the dungeon it was in, so you'd expect it would be.

The game is technically open world, however that doesn't make much difference in practice. Story events must follow a specific path and there's little incentive to venture into areas far above your level. There are some gated areas too. They do a good job of marking when a new area is significantly harder than the zone it connects to. I also like the save reminders before important events. I used these as turn back points when I knew there were still side paths I hadn't explored.

It's worth delving into the nooks and crannies since money is relatively scarce. Most of my gear upgrades came from chests or crafting rather than shops. I've seen other reviews complain about this, but I think it was fine. I was constantly striving to get to the next upgrade until the very end of the game when I was able to max out every equipment slot. Leveling up is less impactful than most new gear, but it does allow you to customize your stats if you want to specialize more.

Visuals are impressively done in a retro SNES style that will appeal to any who fondly remember that era. The colors are vibrant and the land is richly detailed. Plants are numerous and diverse; harmless wildlife flutters overhead and scurries underfoot; and the creations of people display signs of life from both present and past.

As you might expect, the soundtrack is also a prominent part of the game. It adds impact to cutscenes and flavor to the world. It may not be very complex but the melodies are pleasant and memorable. I'm glad the soundtrack is included for free in the game files folder.

36235324.review:
I do not normally go out of my way to write a review after finishing a game, but after finishing it a few minutes ago I was too delighted with Ara Fell to not say something. I'm a child of the triple hits - Secret of Mana, Final Fantasy 6, and Chrono Trigger - and occasionally pick up an RPG Maker game here on Steam to feed my inner 10 year old something 16-bit. It didn't take long into my seventeen hours of play to appreciate the extra layers of development that had been put into Ara Fell's creation, compared to the other RPG Maker games I'd played. My favorite of these extras is the amount of fauna roaming the landside. From rabbits, to birds and butterflies, Ara Fell is never a lonely place. I was reminded of another mid-90's game, Tales of Phantasia, in this regard.

For a game with much less hours under its belt than the ones listed above, I thought the main characters were well rounded, interesting, and consistent with unique voices. Even most of the important NPC's packed a developed character in their small fraction of an appearance. 

My biggest complaint is that many of the game play elements I appreciated in the early hours of the game gradually took a back seat as the story entered into the last half of the chapters. Free exploration, the crafting system, and any real need to fight battles on the map all lost their touch. The latter half of the game doesn't have much useful off the beaten path discoveries, I'd often have better gear by the time I could craft a useful item (due to the great gear that can be found during the free exploration of the first half), and it was easy to over level from intentionally fighting every monster group at least once.

I'd say this was all forgivable due to the story structure being able to hold itself up the whole way. I'm glad I played after the introduction of the epilogue, because it gave me just the right balance of both wanting a sequel and feeling like the story was done. 

All in all, Ara Fell has a way of raising the bar on the RPG Maker genre, while being disappointing only in that it doesn't give you more of itself. I’ll be keeping an eye out for more from Stegosoft Games, whether or not they choose to make a direct sequel (yes, please!)

36066529.review:
I don't tend to write reviews, but I feel like this game deserves it. I'll try to keep this short since I tend to ramble.

Overall, I really enjoyed the game. The plot is pretty standard RPG fare, but the character design is quite a bit more interesting. I really did feel like the characters were more believable, and because of that I definitely got more attached to them. As others have likely said in their reviews, even the villians are written well - they have their own reasonings for doing what they're doing, and you can feel somewhat sympathetic towards them. Somewhat, anyway.

Controls/UI wise, the game played well. I found it odd that ending a battle with a character selected and ready to attack caused parts of the UI to overlap, but I suspect that's a problem with RPG Maker itself. I am VERY glad that there is controller support now, the game picked up my Wii U pro controller without issue. Although, I expect the game would play just as well on keyboard.

I will say that I found the inventory somewhat hard to manage when it came to buying new equipment and comparing stats sometimes, but again, guessing that's a restriction of RPG Maker.

Graphics and sound, I think is somewhat subjective. I know some people LOVE this sort of retro/pixel theme (I'm one of them), but I understand others may not. I will say that I loved the music in this game as well, but I also am a fan of this style of music anyway.

Now for my only real issue with the game, at least in some ways... difficulty. Overall, the game wasn't terribly hard, but I also went out of my way to explore absolutely everything, do all of the sidequests, etc. I only really had to grind once, and that was before I got my full party. After that, I felt like just doing sidequests and occasionally clearing out monsters as I traveled to new areas sustained my leveling. I feel like random encounters are a bit unbalanced in terms of the difficulty/exp given ratio. Maybe I'm incorrect, but there's one specific location with easier enemies early on that was just far easier to grind at than anywhere else available at that time, and it was because those enemies didn't get upgraded after getting my full party together like everything else did.

As for coins, I felt like random encounters were a bit stingy, but at the same time I also didn't have any issues funding my potion uses throughout the game. This may be because of all of the sidequesting, or it may be because all of the smaller amounts from each random encounter added up.

And for a couple random points before I end this... random encounters. There aren't any. You can clearly see where monsters are, and you can just... avoid them if you prefer. This made this game FAR more enjoyable, since I tend to hate random encounters in video games. Another random point is poison/other status effects - I NEVER found any sort of item or spell that could cure status effects, and that irked me a little. I do understand they contribute to the difficulty, but I wish I had some sort of ability to counter it. It didn't seem like the heal spells did anything against them, at least in my experience.

I think that's everything, and this ended up being ridiculously long as I expected it would be. Oh well... to summarize - I loved my time playing this game, and I feel like you would too, if you enjoy RPGs with interesting and believable characters and a good story. While it does have a few flaws here and there with the difficulty and a couple of (purely visual) UI issues, it's overall a well put together game. To give a number of hours, my second attempt at playing it was around 15-16 hours, and that's with me attempting to find most of the secrets this game had to offer (and likely still missing things). Not an extremely long game, but well worth the price, in my opinion. Thanks for reading (suffering through?) my rather rambly review.

36060447.review:
Story and characters: I like how Lita's hero(ine)'s journey was portrayed and how instead of instantly getting used to her role, she struggles with the pressure of being responsible for Ara Fell's safety, as well as how she struggles to control her new power. I also like how the major vampires (save Baramon) aren't flat villains and have their own sympathetic reasons for wanting the Sunstone. However, Doren's love life seems like it could be written better, [spoiler]especially in the epilogue where he seems to get back together with Talani mainly to repopulate their race. [/spoiler]Additionally, I think some characters' backstories should have had flashbacks, especially in the case of Baramon, Nash, and Doren, to flesh them out.

Gameplay: 

The good news is that the bosses are balanced so that lone bosses have much higher speed than a properly leveled (or even overleveled) party, making it so that the player's headcount advantage isn't enough to curbstomp the enemy. In contrast, group bosses are more evenly matched with the player in speed, though they should probably be given a bit more HP so that they can't be cheesed with AOE skills.

Like many players might have stated, the strategy for all bosses after Nash's first encounter is pretty much the same, due to how overpowered Doren's buff song is. It's pretty much a "do everything" buff that requires very little thought. Additionally, there's little incentive to use any of Seri's spells other than her Elemental Burst spells, since most random enemies will die before status effects become useful on them. And bosses tend to resist most status effects, making it pointless to use any element other than maybe ice to lower their defense. I guess players can challenge themselves by not using Elven Song or Elemental Burst.

The crafting system makes it easy to get some good equipment early, but I find that crafting potions is pretty pointless. The total sell amount of all the ingredients for a potion exceeds their price in a shop, meaning players are better off selling the ingredients to buy items. This could be remedied by making the crafting system generate multiple items so that crafting is more efficient than using the shop.

Personally, I think the EXP rate should be lowered and the money drops should be increased. Even though I found a specific area (south of the Springs) where the EXP was low compared to the money and sellable item drops, I still felt like I leveled too quickly before I could afford to buy what I wanted.

The touch encounters are a nice feature and are implemented in a way where the monsters don't chase you too quickly and there's still some room to move around them, making it possible to avoid them if the player is skilled enough. Many other games implement this in a way where the enemies may as well elite security guards who are nearly as wide as the hallways that they're guarding.

The stat building system is designed in a way where every stat is useful while making it inexpensive to reset one's choices, making it a more fun and less anxiety inducing than if all stat decisions are final. This allows the player to freely experiment with different builds while getting used to the game's balance.

3.5/5

35977327.review:
[h1]🎮 [u]Ara Fell[/u] 🎮[/h1]

Ara Fell ist ein klassisch rundenbasiertes RPG, welches mit dem [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362870/RPG_Maker_2003/]RPG Maker 2003[/url] erstellt und entwickelt wurde. Inspiriert wurde es von "Buffy - Die Vampirjägerin" und erinnert stark an Konsolenklassiker wie Zelda, Chrono Trigger oder Final Fantasy. Einige Spieler neigen dazu Ara Fell als eines der besten RPG-Maker-Spiele zu bezeichnen, welches in all den Jahren entwickelt wurde. Leider nur mit englischer Sprachausgabe.

[b]Setting und Gameplay[/b]

Während die meisten RPG-Maker-Titel mit vorgefertigten Texturen und Tilesets daher kommen, gab man sich bei Ara Fell Mühe und individualisierte viel, sodass eine liebevoll und detailreiche Welt kreiiert wurde, die in einer Pixel-Retro-Grafik daher kommt. Diese Mühe machte man sich auch beim Komponieren und Erstellen des Soundtracks, welcher wirklich zum Spiel passt, abgestimmt wirkt und die Atmosphäre steigert. Somit rentiert sich auch das Erkunden der scheinbar unendlich groß wirkenden Open-World-Welt, denn man merkt gar nicht richtig wie man in selbige eintaucht und in sie versinkt. In meinen Augen ein emminent wichtiger Punkt bei Rollenspieltiteln, wenn die Atmosphäre stimmt.  

Dabei spielen auch die Charaktere, welche ebenfalls liebevoll designed sind, eine große Rolle. Mit Persönlichkeiten ausgestattet, gestalten sich die Dialoge als sinnvoll und angenehm. Es passt einfach! Die Story orientiert sich, wie schon erwähnt, ein Stück weit an Buffy und ist gut erzählt, lässt zum Schluss jedoch ein paar Fragen offen und wirkt daher abgehackt. Früher gab es einige Probleme mit dem Controller-Support, welche seit dem 8. Oktober und einem [url=http://steamcommunity.com/games/440540/announcements/detail/1457336803399631280]Major Update[/url] jedoch ad acta gelegt werden kann. Ich hatte jedenfalls beim wiederholten Durchspielen mit dem XBox 360 Wireless keine Probleme mehr. 

Beim Balancing scheiden sich wie so oft die Geister. Zu schwer, ausgewogen/unausgeglichen oder zu einfach? Das ist eine individuelle Frage und muss jeder für sich entscheiden. Erfahrene RPG-Spieler werden sich zurecht finden und ihr Urteil selbst fällen, aber auch Anfänger haben schnell den richtigen Weg gefunden.

[b]Fazit[/b]

Das Spiel kann man, im Vergleich zu den meisten anderen komerziellen RPG-Maker-Titeln, empfehlen. Die Entwickler haben wirklich viel Zeit und Mühe in das Spiel gesteckt und das merkt man auch. Die Spielzeit beträgt circa 15 Stunden ehe man das Ende erreicht hat. Sicherlich gäbe es Spiele die mehr Spielzeit generieren, aber qualitativ vergleichbare Spiele sind rar gesät. Hinzu kommt der für solche Spiele unüblich stark daher kommende Soundtrack. Meine Spielesammlung und die Aktivität auf Steam seit März 2004 sollten als Erfahrung und um das beurteilen zu können, ausreichend sein. Gute Spiele und Entwickler sollte man unterstützen. Das ist hier der Fall!

[i]Falls euch das Review weiter geholfen hat, folgt unserem [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/-German_Gamer_Community-#curation]Reviewprogramm[/url][/i]

35949791.review:
Ara Fell is a competent little RPG that did quite a lot with RPG Maker 2003. The combat system is good, though lacking some variety desipte the unique mechanics that several of the bosses introduce, the music is really good, and the maps are gorgeous with lots of little secrets to find.

The game also respects your time. There are tons of prompts to save before cutscenes and bosses (since afaik this engine doesn't support autosaves), and nearly every cutscene can be skipped outright. There's also a story mode that gives you an option to just autowin any combat if you don't want to engage with it.
 
It's a solid 12-15 hour RPG with some cool ideas, and a plot that is mildly generic but has some high points. My only real complaint is the character portraits could use some updating to match better with the official art and maybe dump the default RPGMaker font for something prettier.

I think it was worth the ten bucks I spent on it and look forward to the next game Stegosoft puts out, as it should be a competent followup.

35825772.review:
I'm kind of torn on this one. The reason I bought and finished this game, was because it reminded me of Final Fantasy VI, which is my favourite oldschool RPG of all time. However, the more I progressed in Ara Fell, the more I noticed on what could've been done better. In the next bits, I will take Ara Fell and Final Fantasy VI at face value and outline the differences between these two games.

1. First of all, I want to focus on the gameplay. I usually like turn-based combat, if it is accompanied by some feeling of progression, inventive (boss-/enemy-) mechanics and consequently, adequate difficulty spikes. I can't deny that Ara Fell's combat gets the progression-part down, still, there is a lot to be desired on the latter aspects.
If you ever encounter a boss with a new mechanic, these won't affect you much (Debuff every round, kill everything around the boss first, etc.). 

In Final Fantasy VI, I remember encountering a boss that would randomly possess one of your characters without any indication of who the possessed one might be. While the boss stays invulnerable, you have to find out who the possessed character may be, by killing them yourself one by one.
To me this is one of many examples of how to make turn-based combat infinitely more interesting, engaging and tactical.

2. Now to the plot. Ara Fell has a very passable plot, although it is a little generic imo. Essentially, it's all about saving the world from the bad guys with a little help of some artifacts and so on. 

It would be unfair to compare this plot to FF VI, as Ara Fell is a 15 hour game at most.

3. And finally the music. I'm usually not a fan of video game music, but I happened to like the first track at the start of the game a lot. The rest of the soundtrack is pretty solid, though these songs didn't surprise me like the first one. 

It's mostly the same concerning the music of Final Fantasy VI. The soundtrack is solid all in all, though I wouldn't listen to any of that given the opportunity.

There's a lot I wanted to point out like e.g. animated facial expressions, but I feel like cutting it short here. 

In conclusion, Ara Fell feels like a mini-RPG, content- and plotwise. It doesn't drag on to long, everything is clearly explained, the characters are okay, the plot is okay and the visuals are neat. All in all, this game may be good for people who haven't ever played any RPG and want to try something new. 

I personally appreciate and understand the effort of the one person who made this game by himself, which despite its shortcomings warrants a thumbs up.

35702942.review:
I don't use Steam. I use 2 other websites for my gaming, but I specifically got steam just so I could buy this. This game is sincerely the real deal; a JRPG, that (SUCCESSFULLY) brought together so many things to love - making it so much more than a conventional JRPG. I cannot express how disapointing it is that I keep seeing "great for RPG Maker" or "can't even tell it's RPG Maker", even though they are compliments. The creators are professionals at their craft, and it pains me knowing that people simply dismiss this based on the RPG Maker tag.

Long review short; I played all the great JRPGs from back in the day. All of them. Ara Fell is a love letter to those with many updated features. The combat is relatively standard (no random encounters), but perfectly balanced; albeit maybe a bit too easy (for me). The story is the best to come from a jRPG in a LONG time. The world is open and beautiful with wonderful music to suit. Characters are loveable and engaging; customization of characters comes down to equipment, skills, and stats. :lita:

Those are simply the footnotes (I don't want to give too much). This game REALLY has SO much more to offer. If you like RPGs, Japanese or any other, you should get this. It's as close as you can come to a perfect 2d jRPG.

35560346.review:
I am rewriting my review from scratch. This may be a pretty long one because I would try to go in depth here. MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!

I wrote this review when I spent 5 hours in the game and I was telling myself "It is not bad but if  it did get so overwhelmingly possitive reviews your game will surely do so too!" I was almost sure about that as the game started as a an usual jRPG - a very unique idea in the center and a lot of cliched tropes filling the rest of the game.
The main plot line was likeable but the side quest were there just for the sake of having some side quests. I guess most of you are already tired of killing N amount of monsters to help someone "clear the infested area" or to "control the population". Did any of you feel the urgency to capture the Rangers' Guild bounties? I doubt it. These supposed criminals seemed to not be related to the rest of the world at all. Hell, the supposedly horrible bandits even refused to kill a party of warriors that kept attacking them.
Also, the character's roles and powers were debateable. Adrian was a heavily armored peasant boy and Seri Kesu was a great mage who happened to get her ass handled to her by some bandits and by most  of the monsters wandering around aimlessly.
As the game continued on though I started seeing better and better why this game was so successful. It has characters you start to care for. Despite the world being very unrecogniseable amongst the most of the other fantasy worlds the game had a cast of characters that you need to see winning, overcoming all the obstacles and saving the day. I can bet that the world build was not the premise but was done mostly to serve the characters and the conflict between them. The author knew the story he would tell long before he knew how Silvara fed itself and most probably even before he knew how a half of the world is super cold and the other is cosy warm.
Having said that I need to address the few issues I had with the plot. I would skip the cliches like the arrow splitting the previous one in half, the unlikely hero, the prophecy, the traitor who becomes the main villain etc. Tropes became tropes because they were successful but still I dislike it. I disliked the most of deus ex machina moments we had, especially the Talani one. I never really used Talani and I ignored her all the way. Her saving the day had no impact on me and deus ex machina having no impact is a failure by definition (at least for me). The moment with the dwarves saving the day in the grove was okay and I guess that the army coming to Lita's aid at the end was okay but a little overdone by having even her little brother come to fight Baramon (WTF?! What were they thinking?!) Also, the Asari one was pretty out of place IMO. The destruction of the Sunstone was anticlimactic. Also, I was kicking Kefk...uh, Baramon's butt until he pulled off a 9999 attack out of his sleeve which I tend to despise. And I could not agree with how things turned out for Nash or to be more precise what Nash did until the end. I think that he should've joined forces with Lita. These and even more moments pulled me out of the game and its world.
However, even if there were 10-20-30 such moments it is not too much as I tend to be more critical usually and this happens with each and every game I play. For example I liked the variety of movement - jumping and swimming but I felt that it got overused at some point (especially the swimming). Also, there were a lot of places with an open area at the end of the map. I get that it looks better but it is not a good thing. You create a rule ("The map ends in an open spot = you can go to another map") and you do not break it. At least that is what I value more than the otherwise very good mapping.
Overall the game held well and I liked the most of it except for the battle system. I tend to prefer the turns before the timer based and the hybrid ones. I disliked it not only because of that though. It just felt non-responsive most of the time. It felt super unpredictable in terms of who comes first and if I would be able to just click faster and heal/attack before I receive an enemy attack or not.
Overall I think that this game suffered from it being started by a developer who grew up and started understanding what makes a fantasy world better but did not want to drop his project. The game starts slow and rather usual but as the plot continues forward it is becoming more and more interesting and better overall.
I listed pros and cons below. They turned out to be an equal amount but IMO the pros overweight the cons by a signifcant margin. I liked the game a lot and although I have been super critical here I really see what it did right and it even inspired me to keep on working on my own project and finish it some day.

Pros, Could've-been-betters and Cons:
+ Easily the best mapping I have ever seen from an RPGM game
+ Heroes were well fleshed out and likeable
+ Customizable stats
+ No random encounters
+ Interesting plot
+ Good music

* Crafting is not bad but had more potential than that
* Skills had more potential than that
* The world build is okay but I think that more could've been done here

- A lot of clichés
- A few bad deus ex machina moments
- Very slow, non-coordinated and sometimes frustrating combat
- Mostly ininteresting level design with the exception of the flying circles but they get old fast
- Uninteresting side quests
- Somewhat uninteresting weapon/armor system

Overall:
I loved the game. It came at the right moment and gave me the spark I needed to restart work on my own projects and assured me that I am on the right track. However, I would prefer that we stop reusing Tolkien's ideas and start seeing more unique fantasy content. I guess a sequel or a game that takes place in the Abbyss somewhere would be a nice place to start.

35507867.review:
Castle In The Sky meets Blade?! I love this game! I was hoping for a long, immersive RPG with a great story, fun side quests, and funny NPC dialogue (Talani!), and Ara Fell delivered. Exploration is rewarded but the map doesn't feel overwhelmingly vast.

I appreciated some aspects of this game which differ from similar RPGs - mainly the feminist bent (female lead and other ambitious female characters) and unique weapons (no swords!).

Looking forward to the next game from Stegosoft!

34765255.review:
You know, usually I try to stay away from RPGMaker games. While I love the concept of having this open software that anyone can make games on, in my experience the RPGMaker games that I've played in the past have been low effort, low quality works that just aren't fun to play.

Luckily, Ara Fell is not one of those.

Ara Fell has a coherent, enjoyable story to follow. It's not the most original concept, I guess, but it's not cheesy, it's not forced, and it's just kinda.. good. It's a good story, and it was fun to experience it.

The path through the story is complex enough to be challenging, but not overly convoluted to make you lose your way and wander. At the same time, you /can/ wander around if you want to. It's not entirely open world, but it lets you off the rails enough to explore and have fun in the world. Maybe try to find some secrets.

Gameplay is pretty standard for an RPGMaker game. Turn-based, which I personally enjoy, and a reasonable system of skills to work with. 

It's just good. No, it's not a mind-blowing masterpiece, but I can say it's probably the best experience that I've ever had playing an RPGMaker game, and I enjoyed it enough that I e-mailed the company to ask if they're making more. (Good news, more games!)

Absolutely worth the money, which is more than I can say for a lot of these types of games.

33779826.review:
I don;t know how these work persay, but I wish to say ahead of time, please let this rate Very Positive.

The land of Ara Fell is a special place, groups of Islands floating in the sky for untold ages, families living in caves made into homes, nature and magic living in peace side by side. Of course such a lovely utopia can't go unspoiled forever and even though this is a review, I'm not spoiling the story, as this is the reason you are buying this game.

The Story is amazing, and for those who wish to experience it, the developer has included a "story mode" attack. It will, in essence, end any battles you encounter, and I would highly recommedn you choose to have it, not because the game is hard persay, in fact I find it pretty well balanced in terms of enemy strength vs player strength, but because there are times you want to get to the next story bit and it will make things much easier. The characters, not just the main cast but any npc who gets more then 2 boxes of dialogue feel very fleshed out and you'll fnd yourself agreeing with them many times. A lot of User Friendly features have been put in to help you get aquainted to the game world and how the game itelf works, and while some of them may feel a little hand holdy (The game will flat out warn you that your hitting a Point of No Return and offer to save, then offer to let you back out of continuing, but to its credit, it also lets you skip long cutscenes should you have died to a boss and are going back)

It's not perfect, as there are a few clear polish issues that I discovered, like difficulty in figuring out what was a decoration on the ground and what would actually heed my progress moving forward, towards the end of the game my character seemed to acquire the ability to jump when going horizontally (though there was a "reset jumping" option that may have fixed that that I never tried) and a large one in that I completed a side quest involving a old necklace and while the game informed me I'd gotten a new item, I had to stop playing shortly after and when I came back, I still had the old necklace and the quest giver was gone (i.e. quest completed)

Regardless of the few bugs mentioned above, if you are or ever were a fan of JRPG's that didn't rely on shoving a world big enough to qualify as a GTA game, wish for a showing of how Narrative can be a bigger draw then combat, or just want to relive the days of old, Ara Fell will certainly scratch that itch.

This is definitely not your usual RPGMaker game. It's pretty for a 16-bit style game. I loved the music. I liked the story. It was pretty obvious where it was going, but it was still well-told and well-thought-out. The lore is entrenched in the game; many of the NPCs give tiny bits of the background, and the NPCs change over time. This is the kind of detail that really shows passion.

It genuinely feels like an mid-16-bit era RPG. Not as polished as, say, Final Fantasy VI, but above Lufia.

The biggest problem is that the engine itself shows its age. It desperately needs a combat speed increase. There are also a few times in which it's easy to get lost because the paths don't show up as obviously as they should.

All that said, if that's the worst I can say about a game, it's worth playing.

33143508.review:
A surprisingly solid and engaging RPG. I even found myself getting emotionally invested in the predictably cliche moments, and the story still managed to subvert a few of those. The characters were surprisingly charming and had a fun dynamic with each other. The music was good, the environments were nice. Definitely a good experience for money. 

And, hopefully without getting into spoilers, I really liked the ending. So many games nowadays seem to be shying away from solid, satisfying, grand endings, and this game doesn't.

This might count as an upside or a downside depending on the player, but I also found it very easy to break the combat system to the point that, a little over halfway through the game, I could just leave most random encounters on "Auto" and be confident of winning. I still appreciated the option to just turn combat off. More games should have that consideration.

I would say my big con is that this is a game that it's pretty easy to get lost in. It can be hard to find out how to get to where you're supposed to go to next. Also, before you get a lot of fast travel points set up there is a lot of backtracking that can get pretty tedious - especially when often the only way to find out if you're not supposed to be somewhere yet is to wait for the enemies to squash you flat. You get a lot of sidequests early on that you're not supposed to do until much later. It took me a long time to find out how much later. 

Still, definitely a good find and a good experience. Thoroughly recommend.

复古而又精致的一个RPG Maker游戏。

BGM优秀，这点你可以从宣传片的BGM中略窥一二，游戏中的BGM大部分也不比宣传片的差。

画面优秀，我可以说这游戏是我最近几年玩过的RM游戏中画面最好的没有之一。甚至于在我玩过的像素游戏中画面也属前列。

剧情虽然普通但是叙事拿捏得很好很有张力，让人有玩下去的动力。同时主角一行人之间的插科打诨也经常会让人会心一笑。

正反派的人物塑造也拿捏的很到位，主角四人性格迥异却又不流于日式游戏那种庸俗的性格模板，每个人都有自己的性格魅力。反派的吸血鬼领主也塑造的令人扼腕，与他最后的战斗也令人动容。

游戏性上来说我没有试过二周目，而且我估计也没什么二周目的内容，不过在一周目上来说内容还是较为充足的。有游泳、下蹲、定点切换悬浮状态等方式供你探索地图，还有各种隐藏门之类的隐藏要素可以探索。游戏过程中也提供了大概不多于10个的支线任务（我没解锁全）。

游戏难度上来说我前期一路不躲怪只刷怪后期直接风骚走位躲掉大部分怪也仍然感觉比较轻松，没有什么练级的必要。唯一比较坑的一点大概就是最终boss竟然是必败战，让我有种之前打了那么久的辛苦都白费了的感觉……

总评：相当不错的RM游戏，即使在复古JRPG的领域也可以算是一款相当不错的作品。

另：我已导出了该游戏的所有文本，不过可能没什么时间汉化……如有兴趣的话可以steam联系我。

32850882.review:
I remember playing a demo for this in the early 2000s when I was really into the RPG Maker scene. It's pretty nice to see the complete game on Steam more than a decade later.

What really impressed me when I played this originally were the graphics and atmosphere. Everyone who's tinkered with RPG Maker 2003 will recognize the famous REFMAP tilesets, and they're used extremely well here, with a lot of birds, butterflies and critters moving around the maps, which really gives this game an atmosphere which stands out among other RPG Maker projects. It's not the first RPG to use floating islands as a setting, but a lot of Ara Fell's quirks (people living in caves, vampire / elven designs in ruins...) contribute to making it more original.

The music is absolutely amazing. The theme that plays in the quarry caves (and some other places as well, but I heard it there first) is up there with all those SNES and PS1 classics.

The scenario is a bit different from what I remembered from the demo, but It's probably better now (although it still is about a chosen one fighting vampires, it's no longer rife with Buffy references, which is a good thing since it clashed a lot with the setting, on top of being very fanficsey). The writing is good and the characters likeable, even though the main antagonist feels a bit underdeveloped - I liked Vampire Lord Nash better.

Gameplay-wise it uses RPG Maker 2003's default battle system, which I pretty much despise (it tries to emulate Final Fantasy's ATB, but sadly it's extremely slow and clunky, it often interrupts you mid-action and the targeting is awful), although the dev tried to balance the stats / equipment (which is actually pretty rare in RPG Maker games) and make complex boss battles with a lot of special moves and scripted events, so that sweetens the pill. Thankfully, at the beginning of the game, you can also activate a special mode to give you a skill that rains 9999s on the battlefield, which helps with the grinding (I remember adding something like that to my characters whenever I tested RM2003 games, glad the dev thought ahead of me this time).

+ Great visuals and atmosphere
+ Excellent music
+ Interesting boss battles
+ "Story mode" which cuts on grinding

- RM2003 default battle system (I [i]really[/i] don't like it)
- Ending felt a bit rushed

7/10 Despite engine-related woes, it's still leagues ahead of most other RPG Maker games that try to emulate SNES RPGs, and I recommend it if you're into that kind of thing.

So when I first glanced at the game, it looked amazing! It had this whole "Secret of Mana" vibe with a tinge of "Illusian of Gaia" with it's text, it's gameplay semi resembled games like Breath of Fire and Final Fantasy, or even Treasures of the Rudras.

That all caught my eye and it stood out amongst the other RPG maker games out there, so I did a little more research. I checked the official YouTube video to see it's ratings. Good amount of views and good ratings usually mean people generally like the game. I then checked Steam reviews, not for the reviews themself, but for the average amount of time people had put into this game. I didn't want to buy a game that had like 2 hours of gameplay alone, I was looking for something that had more like 20+ hours, especially for an RPG. This game DOES have that apparently, based on the average amount of hours involved.

So, I bought Ara Fell and immediately ran into a problem. The game launched in a window instead of fullscreen which most games do immediately. This is fine, just really odd. The problem I ran into was that my corded Xbox 360 controller wasn't recognized and my keyboard couldn't control any of the keys... 

Not a good start for Ara Fell. I tried different USB slots thinking it could be the engine didn't detect USB 3.0 or something, nothing worked. I finally took to the game's steam forum and searched "controller" (which I shouldn't at all have to do, the game should work out of the box!) and found some work around with launching the game with new compatability settings (XP service pack 3).

So I finally launched the game and it worked fine with the controller, I was even able to set the game to fullscreen and stretch it's aspect ratio to fit my monitor; however, after playing a few minutes of the game, I immediately noticed input lag in some areas of the game. I have no idea what's causing this as my PC has updated hardware, enough to play higher-end games like Blizzard's "Overwatch" and Funcom's "Conan Exiles". My guess is the RPG Maker engine isn't optimized for "Windows 10 64-bit, or the code within RPG maker isn't optimized, and thus, the game just lags. It could also be me running the game under that forum poster's suggestion of running the game with Windows XP Service Pack 3 compatability. 

Pros
+Beautiful music
+Stunning sprite work
+Lush thought-provoking story
+Non-linear exploriation
+Diverse crafting system
+Storydriven Cutscenes
+Rewarding Minigames

Cons
-Work arounds are required to use controller and fix lag...
-No diagional movement, can only move Up/Down/Left/Right.
-No battle music, boss music, or fanfare themes.
-Very laggy/almost not useable Crafting System.
-Convoluted, frustrating, and esoteric map system.
-No hotkeys for key features of the game, such as item menu, world map, or crafting menu.
-Cannot Shift+Tab to open steam menu

- Excellent story-driven rpg. Quantity and quality.
- Characters are many and mostly well developed. The main good and evil characters in this game are very relatable and realistic compared to the most famous RPGs.
- Environments are amazing and have never looked so alive in this art style. 
- Surprisingly enough, the story is even better and easily the best aspect of the game. 
- Fighting is simple once you figure out the best options, but by that time you will be all into the story. No grinding.
- Side-quests are well blended into the game and just the right amount.
- Nice soundtrack. A handful of music tracks are perfectly fitting the situations they're used in. The rest is enjoyable, apart from a couple of uninspired ones. Still, it is the kind of music you would not mind to listen to also outside of the game.

The ending makes you wish for a sequel in this same world, maybe even with another group of heroes, maybe in another region or time. This to me means that the game is able to draw you into its world and make you care about it, which is rare.

Well done to the developers!

This is my first review and this game definitely deserves writing a review. This Game is Amazing. It found a perfect harmony between leveling and story progression, meaning you get to enjoy the awesome battle music and cool 16 bit battle effects without ever getting even slightly bored. Not only is the battle music good, but the music more generally is spectacular, easily comparable to that of some of the legendary JRPGs like Corpse Party and such. The story is also both gripping and emotive, with characters that won't fail to elicit a reaction because there are very few characters are clear-cut good or evil, with you potentially pitying your adversaries and questioning your allies, while never failing to make its elements of subtle humor get a laugh. All in all, Ara Fell is infinitely worth the price, with upwards of 12 hours of content that you will enjoy every second of.
Seriously, if you like any JRPGs you HAVE to buy this game :)

TLDR: Good story in a JRPG style game. Recommended for anyone looking for a classic type game. Definitely worth the asking price of $10. Overall 9/10 score.

Overall a very enjoyable game. Grading scale is for a $10 RPG Maker game, baseline score for average is 5/10.

Graphics: 9/10- Lot of detail and effort put into making everything. Multitude of monsters, characters, and general effects

Soundtrack: 9/10- I really enjoyed the soundtrack with the exception of one song.

Gameplay: 7/10- Standard ATB style like FF7 or the like. Once you get the hang of all the skills, the game boils down to multi-target vs single target strategy. Considering the variety of skills overall, I can give it a positive review, but not overwhelmingly so.

Story: 9/10- I was pleasantly surprised of the details of the story. All party characters were fleshed out very nicely and I definitely enjoyed the interactions between characters.

Developer: 10/10- The reason the game won't get an overall 10/10 is due to the bugs, but I felt there should be a special note for how helpful and prompt Stegosoft was when I encountered a bug which would have negatively impacted my playthrough. Within 24 hours of posting the bug in the forums I was presented with a solution. After they physically altered my save file, I was then able to continue playing as normal. I plan on buying their next game upon release for this fact alone.

31475608.review:
Short version; if you like old school JRPGs, you will like this game. It's good. It's shorter and has less content, overall, than AAA titles from back in the day like Chrono Trigger or Secret of Mana, but it is still worth playing.

Longer version; I mostly only have positive things to say about this game. The music is enjoyable; the songs are short and loop alot, but they are still good and I didn't find it annoying at any point. Obviously, as an RPG Maker game, it has sprite graphics and is pretty predictable, but it is done well and they tried to use alot of the available effects. The world is fairly large and detailed and very, very beautiful. The story is a little on the predictable side, but it's still heart-warming and funny and sad and everything I like my JRPGs to be. Characters have 5 stats to increase and 5 equipment slots, and a fair amount of equipment, so there's some depth to it, although again, it's not equivalent to a Final Fantasy. Combat is fairly hard early on, but gets easier. 

This actually leds into one of the only complaints I have about this game; the pacing. Early on, you are given access to alot of places and fights you can't possibly win. Stores stock literally ALL of the pucrhaseable equipment right from the start. For crafting, you can make most stuff very early, and you can see everything you can make from the start as well, allowing you to plan around it. What this is all kind of means is, you aren't sure what you should do. I like having options in a game, but at the same time, the old standard of having new gear at every store kind of helps keep you on track. What I ended up doing here was muscling through the first chapter or so without spending hardly any money, and then I started buying the strongest armor available, one piece at a time. It was a bigger boost to get one piece of level 4 gear than getting several pieces of level 2 gear. But then you end up finding alot of mid-level gear in the game, so it really is just strange. The combat difficulty starts out moderately hard, then, it just gets easy, with an embarassingly east final boss. The story can feel that way too; sometimes it feels like you are taking FOREVER to get through one event, and sometimes it skips along too fast. It's a little bit unsatisfying near the end too, for various reasons, but the game really needed an epilogue. 

So basically, like I said, it's a solid game. Bit short, almost completely lacking in any kind of replay value, but it was very worth playing. If the team behind it makes another game that's a little bit longer, a little bit more spread out with an even pace, they'll will have a fantastic title. This is proof that RPG Maker games can be worth your money, if the devs use it right.

The environments and puzzles are fun and the dialog and story are original and never boring. Also the music is excellent and worlds are beautiful and detailed and interesting to explore. I actually got this game after watching someone else playing it and it looked fun.
